title: Ray Dalio worried by Trump's capital punishment
text:
The problem for Dalio is history shows it never ends well when the US President uses their authority – as happened in the 1930s and 1940s against Japan – to restrict capital flows or the ownership of US assets.

But that's what the White House and members of Congress are considering.

Whether it's the Equitable Act legislation (which seeks to delist non-compliant Chinese companies from US stockmarkets) or possible restrictions on the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board from investing in the MSCI All Country World ex-US Index, there is an impulse within sections of the Trump administration to use capital markets to curtail China's emergence as a peer challenger to US dominance.

Dalio asks the question that seems to have evaded those pondering the use of capital flows as a weapon: "How would you feel if you were an adversarial foreign investor holding US bonds given this situation, given where US bond interest rates are and the impending deficits and monetizations of them?"

Warning that China dumping US bonds – of which they own $US1.1 trillion ($1.6 trillion) – would have "its own terrible consequences", he lamented that "from not having to worry about such things in the past, now all market participants need to worry about them".

Like global markets needed more to worry about. The global growth outlook cannot take any more angst in the US and China relationship.

The grim September ISM survey – it fell to 47.8 from 49.1 in August – highlighted the threat to the US economy from the weak global growth, lacklustre trade and a strong US dollar.

Advertisement

The tough times in the US industrial economy speaks to another point of concern: has the US Federal Reserve acted boldly enough with two cuts in as many meetings to underwrite growth in the world's largest economy?

BNY Mellon FX and macro strategist John Velis said the employment component of the ISM sends a negative signal about the prospects for the US jobs market. This will test the US central bank, which has signalled it's in no rush to ease monetary policy again.

"This reinforces our view that while the Fed is still stubbornly clinging to its view that rates are currently appropriate for an economy that continues to perform well, it will ultimately have to accept that the pillars of support – the labor market and the consumer – are weakening," said Velis.

Trump v Powell

Futures markets priced in a 60 per cent chance of another 25 basis point cut at the Federal Reserve's October meeting after the ISM numbers, up from 40 per cent beforehand.

If it wasn't bad enough that traders are betting the Fed will need to cut again, Fed chair Jerome Powell received yet another dose of constructive criticism from President Trump who said the central bank doesn't "have a clue" and was "pathetic".

Unfortunately, Trump's crash or crash-through approach may have worked in New York's 1980s property scene, but in a world looking for certainty and clarity it's little wonder that the smart money are worried.
description: The boss of the world's largest hedge fund says all investors "need to worry" about capital flow retributions becoming a new weapon in the trade war.
